questions.text: Which is formed by 3 bones?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Foramen Magnum is present in occipital bone. Option B-Foramen jugulare is present between petrous part of temporal bone and occipital bone. Option C-Foramen rotundum is present in sphenoid bone. Option D-Foramen lacerum contributed by petrous part of temporal bone,sphenoid & occipital bone.

questions.text: Which of following structure passes via jugular foramen has separate canal:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-12th Nerve does not pass through jugular foramen rather,it passes through hypoglossal canal. Option B-9th Nerve has a separate canal while passing through jugular foramen. Option C,D-10th and 11 th Nerve passes together through jugular foramen.

questions.text: Identify the marked foramen/canal
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-foramen rotundum is present in greater wing of sphenoid bone as shown in picture,maxillary nerve passes through it. Option B-F.ovale is present in greater wing of sphenoid bone,but as the name suggests it is oval in shape and it lies behind the foramen rotundum, Option C-Vidian canal connects foramen lacerum to pterygopalatine fossa. Option D-Incisive foramen is present on the palatal surface of maxillary bone.

questions.text: Through which of the marked foramen, Covid may spread to meninges ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Covid may spread to meninges through Cribiform plate of ethmoid as shown in label A,from where olfactory nerves are passing, and hence covid can cause meningitis & encephalitis. Option B-Label B is foramen ovale through which mandibular nerve passes. Option C-Label C is internal acoustic meatus through which facial and vestibulocohlear nerve passes. Option D-Label D is jugular foramen through which 9th,10th, and 11th nerve passes.

choices.text: Taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue
General sensation from anterior 2/3rd of tongue

questions.text: In case of trauma to jugular foramen which of the following function is lost?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue is carried by chorda tympani,branch of facial nerve. Option B-Through jugular foramen, 9th 10th 11th Nerve Are passing through.and we know taste in posterior 1/3rd of tongue is carried by 9th Nerve which passes through jugular foramen. Option C-General sensation from anterior 2/3rd of tongue is carried by lingual nerve,bnranch of mandibular nerve. Option D-All motor function of tongue are carried out by by XII Nerve which passes through hypoglossal canal.

questions.text: Identify the marked nerve in the base of the skull ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-There is nothing known as ocular nerve. Option B-Marked arrow is 3rd nerve i.e,Oculomotor nerve,and Thickest looking is 5th Nerve. Option C-Hypoglossal nerve passes through Hypoglossal canal. Option D-Glossopharyngeal nerve passes through jugular foramen.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve supplies the marked structure in the given pic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-CN 2 i.e,optic nerve is sensory and do notsupply any muscles. Option B-Labelling is on the superior oblique muscle [SO4] which is supplied by CN 4 as we can see it is present superiorly and it lies outside the cone formed by recti muscles. Option C-CN 3 i.e,oculomotor nerve supplies all extraocular muscles except lateral rectus and superior oblique. Option D-CN 6 i.e,abducent nerve supplies lateral rectus.

questions.text: Sequential arrangment of 8th nerve pathway from periphery to center: 1. Vestibular nerve 2. Superior olivary nucleus 3. Medial geniculate body 4. Cochlear nuclei 5. Lateral lemniscus 6. Inferior colliculus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 1-4-2-5-6-3 Mnemonic for 8th nerve pathway is "Spiral CT SLIM 41,42" which is as follows:- •SPIRAL ORGAN OF CORTI •COCHLEAR NUCLEI •TRAPEZOID BODY •SUPERIOR OLIVARY NUCLEUS –CENTER FOF STAPEDIAL REFLEX •LATERAL LEMINISCUS •INFERIOR COLLICULUS •MEDIAL GENICULATE BODY •AREA 41,42 –primary auditory area

choices.text: Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of mandibular Nerve
Supratrochlear Nerve lies lateral to Supra orbital Nerve
Lacrimal Nerve supplies skin of lateral part of upper eyelid

questions.text: Which of the following is false
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of posterior division of mandibular Nerve. Option B-Buccal Nerve pierces Buccinator muscle but doesn't supply it. Option C-Supratrochlear nerve lies Medial to supraorbital nerve(not lateral to it). Option D-Lacrimal Nerve supplies skin of lateral part of upper eyelid is a true statement.

questions.text: All of the following are branches of External carotid artery (ECA) supplying the nasal septum except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of ophthalmic artery which is further a branch of ICA. Option B,C-ECA gives a branch of Maxillary artery which gives 2 branches- greater palatine artery & sphenopalatine artery. Option D-ECA also gives facial artery which further gives superior labial artery.

questions.text: Which of the following marking represents Piriform Fossa
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-A is Epiglottis Option B-B is glottis present between two vocal cords. Option C-C is aryepiglottic fold Option D-D is pyriform fossa which is present lateral to aryepiglottic fold.Frequently,fish bone or foreign body gets stuck here.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of Carotid sheath?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B-Inside the carotid sheath are present- common carotid artery,internal carotid artery & initial part of external carotid artery,vagus nerve. Option C-Upper part of carotid sheath contains 9th to 12th nerve also. Option D-Sympathetic chain lies behind the carotid sheath.hence,it is not a content of Carotid sheath.

questions.text: A Patient who underwent Parotid surgery noticed weakness in lower lip movement after surgery, Which of the following nerve is injured in this patient.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most common nerve injury affecting the lower lip after parotidectomy is the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve. Since "Marginal Mandibular branch" is not an option, there's an issue with the question's options if it expects a single, precise answer. However, let's think if one of the given options could be the intended answer due to some anatomical nuance. The cervical branch innervates the platysma, which can depress the lower lip and angle of the mouth. So, injury to the cervical branch could contribute to perceived lower lip weakness, especially if it's broad depression of the mouth. If the question is well-posed and has a single correct answer among the options, the most plausible link to "lower lip movement" amongst the facial nerve branches listed is the Cervical branch, due to its innervation of the platysma. While the marginal mandibular branch is the direct nerve for specific lower lip depressors, the platysma also contributes to lower facial expression. Therefore, the most likely intended answer, if the marginal mandibular branch is not an option, is B. Cervical branch of Facial Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following structures lies deep to the marked area
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Posterior clinoid process is present posterior to sella turcica. Option B-The marked area is Pterion –lesser wing of sphenoid lies deeper to it and also Deep to it lies middle meningeal artery. Option C-Carotid canal is present in petrous part of temporal bone. Option D-Sella turcica is present on body of sphenoid.

questions.text: Artery lying deep to the marked area is which one of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Ophthalmic Artery passes through optic canal. Option B-Maxillary Artery lies on lateral pterygoid muscle. Option C-Internal Carotid Artery passes through carotid canal. Option D- The marked area is PTERION -deep to it lies middle meningeal artery : Anterior division.It's rupture is the Most common cause of EDH.

questions.text: Third part of vertebral artery is related to which part of atlas?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A- is posterior tubercle. Option B- is related to 3rd part of vertebral artery. Option C- is formaen transversium. Option D- is anterior tubercle.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is least injured in thyroid surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Superior Laryngeal Nerve divides into internal and external laryngeal nerve,external laryngeal nerve lies near the superior pole of thyroid. Option B-Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve lies near the inferior pole of thyroid. Option C-Ansa Cervicalis lies on anterior wall of carotid sheath and hence it lies in close proximity to thyroid. Option D-Marginal Mandibular Nerve is well away from thyroid gland and hence it is least injured in thyroid surgery.

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery is a branch of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Thyrocervical trunk gives branches(SIT) ? suprascapular, inferior thyroid, Transverse cervical. Option B-Costocervical trunk gives rise to Deep cervical branch & superior intercostal branch. Option C-ICA do not supply thyroid. Option D-ECA gives superior thyroid artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not branch of Facial Artery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C,D-Superior labial,Inferior labial and Lateral nasal are branches of facial artery. Option B-Mental artery is given by inferior alveolar branch of maxillary artery.

questions.text: Lesion of which of the following will lead to paradoxical respiration
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-phrenic nerve [scalenus anterior],Lesion of phrenic nerve will lead to paradoxical respiration as it supplies diaphragm. Option B-vagus nerve Option C-subclavian artery Option D-spinal accessory nerve- running down to supply trapezius.

questions.text: Which of the following is the function of the marked muscles?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Protraction is also carried out by medial pterygoid,hence,Depression is a better answer here. Option B-Retraction is caused by temporalis muscle. Option C-Marked muscle is Lateral Pterygoid and it's Action is Protraction and Depression but Protraction is also carried out by medial pterygoid,hence,Depression is a better answer here. Option D-Elevation is caused by masseter.

questions.text: Name of the marked cranial nerve
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Marked nerve is 6th Nerve i.e, Abducent nerve as it is arising at pontomedullary junction. Option B-Glossopharyngeal nerve arises lateral to olive,from the medulla. Option C-Facial nerve also arises from pontomedullary junction but it lies lateral to 6th nerve. Option D-Vestibulocochlear nerve also arises at pontomedullary junction but it lies lateral to 7th nerve.

questions.text: Spinal cord ends at what level in adults?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Spinal cord ends in Adults-at L1. Spinal cord ends in Infants –at L3. Piamater & Duramater will reach coccyx level. Arachnoid reaches upto S2 level. Dural sac is present upto S2 level.

questions.text: Medial Lemniscus is a continuation of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Spinothalamic tract makes the spinal leminiscus. Option B,C-SpinoTectal tract and SpinoCerebellar tract do not form any lemniscus. Option D-Fasciculus gracilis is a part of dorsal column tract and it continues as Medial Lemniscus.

questions.text: Which of the following feature will be seen in Lesion of the marked structure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Ataxia occurs because of cerebellar involvement . Option B-Vertigo occurs because of vestibular nucleus involvement . Option C-The given Swelling at anterior aspect of medulla is the pyramidal tract.If involved- it will lead to contralateral hemiplegia. Option D-Facial nerve palsy occurs because of involvement of facial nucleus

questions.text: Damage to the structure producing the elevation marked, leads to paralysis of which of the following muscle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Lateral rectus is supplied by 6th nerve. Option B-The marked area shows Rhomboid fossa/ floor of 4th ventricle which has facial colliculus,which is a dilation produced by 7th Nerve.Injury to 7th nerve will lead to palsy of risorius muscle. Option C-Levator palpebrae Superioris is supplied by 3rd nerve. Option D-Superior oblique is supplied by 4th nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following sensation is not perceived by spinal nucleus of trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-Pain,Touch and Temperature is perceived by spinal nucleus of trigeminal nerve. Option D-proprioception is perceived by Mesencephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: Purkinje fibers relay to which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) There are 3 layers in cerebellar cortex:- 1. Molecular - basket & stellate cells. 2. Purkinje –purkinje cells –they are connected to deep nuclei of cerebellum(dentate nuclei). 3. Granular layer Afferent fibers of 2 types – 1. Climbing fibers – come from olivary nucleus –connected directly to purkinje fibers. 2. Mossy fibers –connected indirectly to purkinje fibers.

questions.text: There is a Marked area in the given section. Fibers from here will relay in which nucleus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Inferior olivary gives rise to climbing fibers. Option B-Labelled structure is middle cerebellar peduncle which Relays into fastigial nucleus [deep nuclei of cerebellum]. Option C-Red nucleus gives rise to rubrospinal tract. Option D-Tectum gives rise to tectospinal tract.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly marked?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Fornix Option B-B is pituitary stalk Option C-Cerebellum Option D-Corpus callosum

choices.text: Meningeal branch of ICA in posterior cranial fossa
Accessory meningeal artery in Middle cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery in Anterior cranial fossa
Middle meningeal artery in Middle cranial fossa

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding blood supply of dura mater?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Meningeal branch of ICA supplies anterior cranial fossa(not posterior cranial fossa). Option B-Accessory meningeal artery lies in Middle cranial fossa. Option C-Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery lies in Anterior cranial fossa. Option D-Middle meningeal artery lies in Middle cranial fossa.

questions.text: Which of the following projects efferent fibers through the marked structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The marked structure is Fornix and it is the efferent coming from the hippocampus and going towards mammillary body. Option B-fornix sends the signal to Mammillary body. Option C-Caudate nucleus lies in floor of lateral ventricle. Option D-Amygdala is present at tip of tail of caudate nucleus.

questions.text: Fibres from mammillary body ends in which marked area?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-A is anterior nucleus Of thalamus and fibers coming from mammillary body ends here,forming a mammilothalamic tract. Option B-B is ventroanterior nucleus of thalamus which receives fibers from basal ganglia. Option C-C is ventrointermediate nucleus of thalamus which receives fibers from cerebellum. Option D-D is ventroposterior nucleus of thalamus which receives fibers from medial,spinal and trigeminal lemniscus.

questions.text: Limbic system includes which of the following:- A. Hippocampus B. Amygdaloid body C. Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus D. Caudate Nucleus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Limbic system includes Hippocampus,Amygdaloid body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus i.e, A+B+C While Caudate nucleus is a part of basal nuclei.

questions.text: Neurotransmitter secreted by the marked area is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-GABA is secreted by globus pallidus. Option B-Glutamate is secreted by subthalamic nucleus. Option C-Marked structure is Substantia nigra and it secretes dopamine .If dopamine level is decreased,it leads to Parkinson disease. Option D-Ach is secreted by fibers coming from cortex and thalamus.

questions.text: Decussation of Superior Cerebellar peduncle occurs at:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Decussation of Superior Cerebellar peduncle occurs at Midbrain at level of inferior colliculus. Option B-Decussation of auditory fibers occurs at pons. Option C-Decussation of pyramidal tract occurs at lower part of medulla. Option D-Thalamus do not take part in decussation.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of Dysarthria, sensory loss of right side of face, right upper limb ataxia. There is sensory loss of left side of body without motor deficit. Which artery is involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given case scenario is of Lateral medullary syndrome:- Dysarthria-due to involvement of right 10th nerve. Sensory loss of right side of face-due to involvement of right spinal nucleus of trigeminal nerve. Right upper limb ataxia-due to involvement of right vestibular nucelus. Sensory loss of left side of body-due to involvement of right medial meniscus. Without motor deficit as pyramidal tract is not involved. The Most common artery involved in this syndrome is- vertebral artery > PICA

questions.text: Ischemia to which part of internal capsule will lead to contralateral motor loss in upper & Lower limbs?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-thalamic radiations passes through Anterior Limb. Option B-Ischemia to Posterior limb of Internal capsule will lead to contralateral motor loss in upper & Lower limbs as pyramidal tract passes through posterior limb. Option C-optic radiation passes through Retrolentiform part. Option D-temporopontine fibers passes through Sublentiform part.

questions.text: Fornix contains
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fornix contains ASSOCIATION, COMMISURAL, PROJECTION FIBERS >> COMMISURAL & ASSOCIATION FIBERS. Commissure fibers connect corresponding regions of the two hemispheres. Association fibers connect areas within a cerebral hemisphere. Projection fibers connect cerebral hemisphere to spinal cord.

questions.text: Blood supply of the marked structure is:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Marked arrow is Splenium and Splenium is located at the junction of 2 blood supply territory i.e, ACA +PCA

questions.text: SDH is due to injury to which of the following vessel?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Middle Meningeal artery is artery for EDH. Option B-Charcot Artery is artery for CEREBRAL BLEED/ INTRACEREBRAL HEMORRHAGE. Option C-Bridging veins injury leads to subdural hemorrhage. Option D-Middle Cerebral artery leads to intracranial hemorrhage.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given dissection specimen:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Marked structure is ulnar nerve as it is present on ulnar side at guyon's canal. Option B-Ulnar Artery is also present in guyon's canal but it's a luminal structure. Option C-Radial Artery is present on radial side. Option D-Median Nerve lies in carpal tunnel.

questions.text: Which part of brachial plexus does not give any branch?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Roots gives rise to dorsal scapular nerve and long thoracic nerve. Option B-upper Trunk gives rise to suprascapular nerve and nerve to subclavius. Option C-Cords gives rise to numerous branches. Option D-No branch arises from Division.

questions.text: Which of the following finger is having two dorsal interossei muscles:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dorsal interossei is Absent in thumb & little finger. Middle finger has 2 dorsal interossei but doesn’t have any palmar interossei.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles do not contribute to the marked tendon:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Interossei muscles,lumbricals are inserted in dorsal digital expansion which is an expanded tendon of Extensor digitorum.Middle finger has 2 dorsal interossei,lumbricals but doesn’t have any palmar interossei.

questions.text: Which of the following deformity is seen in the lesion of the marked structure :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Claudication can occur due to injury to brachial artery. Option B-Ape thumb deformity occur due to injury to median nerve. Option C-Marked arrow is radial nerve in cubital fossa,lying lateral to biceps tendon.It's injury can lead to wrist drop. Option D-Claw hand occur due to injury to ulnar nerve.

questions.text: Lesion of the marked structure leads to Loss of sensation at :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Marked arrow is median nerve lying medial to brachial artery in cubital fossa which supplies:- Palmar aspect of 3½ fingers,thenar eminence and tip of radial bone is supplied by Median nerve and remaining 1½ fingers and hypothenar eminence by ulnar nerve. On Dorsal aspect – distal phalanges(i.e. nail area) of 3½ are supplied by median nerve rest 2½ of dorsal aspect of hand is supplied by radial nerve & 2½ by ulnar nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following structures in the scapula is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-A is glenoid cavity. Option B-B is acromion. Option C- C is Coracoid process,which is palpable in infraclavicular fossa. Option D-D is inferior angle of scapula.

questions.text: A Patient presented with the deformity as shown in pic. Which of the following nerves are involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Median nerve injury leads to ape thumb deformity. Option B-the deformity as shown in picture is Partial claw hand,also known as Ulnar claw.High ulnar nerve injury leads to less severe claw hand called as ulnar paradox. Option C-Radial nerve injury leads to wrist drop. Option D-Musculocutaneous nerve injury leads to paralysis of biceps,brachialis and coracobrachialis muscle.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the marked muscle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-3rd and 4th lumbricals are supplied by ulnar nerve. Option B-the marked muscle is Lumbrical – 1st and 2nd lumbricals are supplied by Median nerve. Option C-Radial Nerve supplies posterior compartment of forearm. Option D-Musculocutaneous Nerve supplies biceps,brachialis and coracobrachialis.

questions.text: All are involved in over head abduction except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Pectoralis Major performs ADDUCTION,not abduction. Option B-Also deltoid [15-90°] and Supraspinatus [0-15°] do help in initial part of abduction. Option C,D-Overhead abduction is done by Serratus anterior & Trapezius[>90°],

questions.text: Identify the marked muscle
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The opponens pollicis muscle is one of the three thenar muscles. It originates from the flexor retinaculum of the hand and the tubercle of the trapezium. It passes downward and laterally, and is inserted into the whole length of the metacarpal bone of the thumb on its radial side as shown in picture. Option B-for Abductor pollicis brevis,Two smaller origins are located on carpal bones; the first is found on the tubercle of scaphoid while the second is on the tubercle of trapezium bone. After originating from these locations, the muscle fibers form a single muscle belly that runs distally and radially (lateral) towards the thumb. Option C-Flexor pollicis longus comes all the way from forearm to be inserted on base of 1st metacarpal. Option D-First palmar interossei arises from medial palmar surface of the first metacarpal.

questions.text: One patient Is unable to hold the paper between his fingers and presents with the difficulty in flexion of 4th and 5th distal interphalangeal joints. Nerve injury can occur at which part of bone?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-axillary nerve lies around surgical neck of humerus. Option B-B is lateral condyle of humerus. Option C- Radial nerve passes in spiral groove. Option D-As patient Is unable to hold the paper between his fingers [Card test is positive] .It indicates palmar interossei muscles are weak as patient is unable to do adduction,which can occur in ulnar nerve palsy. Also,difficulty in flexion of 4th and 5th distal interphalangeal joints is because of involvement of medial half of flexor digitorum profundus which is also supplied by ulnar nerve.We know ulnar nerve passes behind medial epicondyle of humerus i.e,point D in picture.

questions.text: The test as shown in pic is done for which nerve?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Median nerve injury will show ape thumb deformity. Option B-Book test / froment sign is done for adductor pollicis which is supplied by ulnar nerve.A patient is asked to hold an object, usually a flat object such as a piece of paper, between their thumb and index finger (pinch grip). The examiner then attempts to pull the object out of the subject's hands.A normal individual will be able to maintain a hold on the object without difficulty. With ulnar nerve palsy, the patient will experience difficulty maintaining a hold and will compensate by flexing the FPL (flexor pollicis longus) of the thumb to maintain grip pressure causing a pinching effect. Option C-Radial nerve injury will show wrist drop. Option D-Musculocutaneous nerve injury will lead to weakness of biceps,brachialis and coracobrachialis.

questions.text: Which muscle causes Flexion, lateral rotation and abduction at hip and Flexion in knee
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-FAbER- FLEXION, ABDUCTION, EXTERNAL ROTATION at hip & flexion at knee is done by Sartorius,which is also known as Tailor‘s muscle. Option B-B is vastus lateralis muscle which do not cause any action at hip. Option C-C is gracilis which causes adduction,not abduction at hip. Option D-D is vastus medialis muscle which do not cause any action at hip.

questions.text: During femoral cannulation, which nerve is blocked? 1) Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve 2) Femoral nerve 3) Genitofemoral nerve 4) Obturator nerve
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lateral Femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh supply lateral side of thigh. Femoral nerve and Genitofemoral nerve supply the skin over femoral artery. hence,During femoral cannulation, these nerves are blocked. Obturator nerve supply medial side of thigh.

questions.text: Which of the following structure crosses the marked structure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Sciatic Nerve lies at inferior border of piriformis muscle. Option B-Obturator Nerve exits via obturator foramen. Option C-Inferior rectal Nerve is related to ischioanal fossa. Option D-Marked structure is ischial spine which is related to pudendal nerve as pudendal nerve nerve exits via greater sciatic foramen and re-enter via lesser sciatic foramen.

questions.text: Action of the marked muscle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Marked muscle is gluteus minimus which performs Abduction & medial rotation of hip. [also by gluteus medius]. Gluteus maximus - cheif extensor and lateral rotator of hip. Inferior gluteal nerve supplies gluteus maximus. Superior gluteal nerve supplies gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, tensor fascia lata.

questions.text: Action of the muscle attached to the marked area?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The marked area is Gluteal tuberosity where Gluteus maximus is attached.It performs EXTENSION, EXTERNAL ROTATION, ABDUCTION. gluteus minimus and gluteus medius performs Abduction & medial rotation of hip. Inferior gluteal nerve supplies gluteus maximus. Superior gluteal nerve supplies gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, tensor fascia lata

questions.text: Most common nerve injured at the proximal end of the fibula is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Femoral Nerve lies in femoral triangle of thigh. Option B-Common peroneal nerve winds around neck of fibula.hence,Most common nerve injured at the proximal end of the fibula is Common peroneal nerve.It leads to foot drop+loss of eversion.Deep peroneal nerve is a specific answer for foot drop. Option C-Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh passes behind the lateral end of inguinal ligament. Option D-Saphenous Nerve runs along with great saphenous nerve.

questions.text: All of the following muscles are responsible for inversion except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B-Tibialis anterior and Tibialis posterior performs the inversion.Inversion & eversion takes place at subtalar & midtarsal joints. Option C-Peroneus longus is the muscle of eversion. Option D-Extensor hallucis longus also does the inversion,along with extension of great toe.

questions.text: Compartment of leg without neurovascular bundle is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-ANTERIOR COMPARTMENT has DEEP PERONEAL NERVE. Option B-LATERAL COMPARTMENT has SUPERFICIAL PERONEAL NERVE. Option C-DEEP POSTERIOR COMPARTMENT has TIBIAL NERVE. Option D-Gastrocnemius, Plantaris, soleus [GPS – SUPERFICIAL POSTERIOR COMPARTMENT] are supplied by tibial nerve, but in superficial posterior compartment nerve is not running.

questions.text: Left superior intercostal vein drains into
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Superior intercostal vein is formed by 2nd, 3rd and 4th posterior intercostal veins. On Right side,It drains into azygous vein. On Left side,It drains into left brachiocephalic Vein.

questions.text: Structures arranged from anterior to posterior relations in lung hilum are
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Structures arranged from anterior to posterior relations in lung hilum are VAB i.e., VEIN ,ARTERY and BRONCHUS.

questions.text: All of the following arteries supply the marked part except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The marked area in this question is Right ventricle. Option A,B,D-Marginal artery,Anterior interventricular artery and Right coronary artery all supplies the right ventricle. Option C-Diagonal artery supplies the left ventricle,not right ventricle.

questions.text: Superior boundary of epiploic foramen is formed by:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Epiploic foramen connects lesser sac to greater sac. Option A-Caudate lobe of liver is present superiorly. Option B-IVC lies posteriorly. Option C-Duodenum lies inferiorly. Option D-Lesser omentum is present anteriorly.

questions.text: Structure that divides liver anatomically based on Couinaud’s classification system is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Couinaud classification of liver anatomy divides the liver into eight functionally indepedent segments. Each segment has its own vascular inflow, outflow and biliary drainage. In the centre of each segment there is a branch of the portal vein, hepatic artery and bile duct. It is based on the identification of three hepatic veins and the plane passing by the portal vein bifurcation.

questions.text: During Deep inspiration,the lung extends upto which level of liver?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Till A-B :Lung & pleura,both will reach. Option B-Till B-C :only pleura will reach. Option C-Till C-D :nothing will reach. Option D-Till A-D :as described above,nothing will reach till point D.

questions.text: Which of the following viscera is related to marked area of left kidney:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-2nd part of Duodenum lies in relation to hilum of right kidney. Option B-Liver lies in relation to anterior surface of right kidney. Option C-Left suprarenal & left kidney,as marked in the picture, are part of stomach bed.hence,Stomach is related to marked area of left kidney. Option D-Spleen is related to superolateral surface of left kidney.

questions.text: Identify the Pelvic diaphragm in the below given picture
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-A is internal anal sphincter. Option B-B is external anal sphincter. Option C-C is pelvic diaphragm,formed by levator ani muscle. Option D-D is pudendal canal,which contains internal pudendal vessels and pudendal nerve.

questions.text: Correct sequence of structure in spermatogenesis event: 1. Spermatozoa 2. Spermatogonia 3. Spermatocytes 4. Spermatid
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Correct sequence of structure in spermatogenesis event is:- Spermatogonia>Spermatocytes>Spermatid>Spermatozoa.

questions.text: From which of the following the marked structure develops?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Subcardinal vein gives rise to gonadal vein. Option B-Marked structure is Azygous vein, which is formed by supracardinal vein. Option C-Common cardinal takes part in fromation of IVC. Option D-Anterior cardinal gives rise to internal jugular veins.

questions.text: A young patient with absent thymus and presented with hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked area in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is a case of DiGeorge syndrome,in which 3rd pharyngeal pouch is affected [marked as A] ,which gives rise to thymus & inferior parathyroid.Hence,patient presents with absent thymus and hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Option B-B is 4th pharyngeal pouch which gives rise to superior parathyroid gland and C-cells of thyroid. Option C-C is 2nd pharyngeal pouch which gives rise to palatine tonsils and tonsillar fossa. Option D-D is 1st pharyngeal pouch which gives rise to auditory tube and middle ear.

questions.text: Stellate cells in liver are seen at which location?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Sinsuoids are filled with blood and lined by endothelium. Option B- stellate cells are present in Space of disse and their Role is fat storage [Physiological ] and fibrosis[Pathological role]. Option C-A periportal space (space of Mall), where lymph is produced, is sandwiched between the connective tissue of the portal canals and the hepatocytes. Option D-Bile Canaliculi are filled with bile.

choices.text: Presence of Serous acini with Acidophilic tip
Serous acinus supported by basal lamina

questions.text: Difference between Exocrine pancreas and parotid gland is:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Serous acini with Acidophilic tip is present in both pancreas as well as parotid gland. Option B-Serous acinus supported by basal lamina is also present in both pancreas as well as parotid gland. Option C-No striated ducts are present in pancreas,while they are present in parotid gland. Option D-Apical acinar villi is present in both pancreas as well as parotid gland.

questions.text: Predominant cells present at the isthmus of Gastric pits are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Mucus Cells are found in surface epithelium. Option B,C-Chief Cells and Parietal cells are present deep within the gastric gland. Option D-Isthmus means junction and at the junction, stem cells are present which helps in regeneration of other cells.

questions.text: Transitional epithelium is present in all of the following places except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B,D-Minor calyx,Major calyx, Renal pelvis ,ureter,bladder and Prostatic urethra,all have transitional epithelium. Option C-Membranous urethra has columnar epithelium.

questions.text: Middle radioulnar joint is an example of –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Primary cartilaginous joint-The first sternocostal joint. Option B-Secondary cartilaginous joint-manubriosternal joint (between the manubrium and the body of the sternum), intervertebral discs, and the pubic symphysis. Option C-Middle radio ulnar joint is an example of Syndesmosis [fibrous joint]. Option D-Synovial joints-freely mobile (diarthroses) and are considered the body's main functional joints

questions.text: Type I collagen is present in all of the following locations except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C,D-Bone,Ligament and Aponeurosis have Type I collagen. Option B-Hyaline and elastic cartilages haveType 2 collagen while Fibrocartilage has both type 1 & 2 collagen.

questions.text: What is the content of ligamentum flavum
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Bone,Ligament and Aponeurosis have Type I collagen. Option B-Hyaline and elastic cartilages haveType 2 collagen while Fibrocartilage has both type 1 & 2 collagen. Option C-Reticulin fibres are fine fibres that contain primarily collagen type III and are found in soft blood-forming or blood-processing tissues, and are supportive elements in kidney, liver and thymus. Option D-Ligamentum flavum has high levels of elastin fibres. - The Ligamentum flava are a series of Ligaments that connect the ventral parts of the laminae of adjacent vertebrae. They predominantly contain elastic tissue and form part of the posterior surface of the vertebral canal. The Ligamentum flava resist separation of the laminae in flexion and assist in extension, back to the anatomical position.

questions.text: Which of the following is comprised of Dense irregular tissue:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Lamina Propria is a thin layer of loose (areolar) connective tissue, which lies beneath the epithelium, and together with the epithelium and basement membrane constitutes the mucosa. Option B-Dermis is comprised of Dense irregular tissue. Option C,D-Ligament and Aponeurosis is comprised of Dense regular tissue.

questions.text: Most common hernia in female is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Indirect inguinal hernias can occur in both males and females, but they are more common in males. In females, inguinal hernias are less common compared to males, and when they do occur, they are usually indirect inguinal hernias rather than direct inguinal hernias. An indirect inguinal hernia occurs when a portion of the intestine or other abdominal tissue protrudes through the inguinal canal, which is a passageway in the lower abdominal wall near the groin. This type of hernia is more common in both males and females and is often due to a congenital defect in the abdominal wall. Most common hernia in female is overall is Indirect inguinal hernia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in the floor of inferior horn of lateral ventricle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The lateral part of the roof (lateral wall) is formed by fibres of the tapetum, while the medial part of the roof is formed by the tail of the caudate nucleus and the stria terminalis. Option B,C,D-The floor of the inferior horn is formed mainly by the hippocampus, along with the alveus and fimbriae. In the lateral part of the floor is an elevation called the collateral eminence, produced by inward bulging of the white mater which lies deep to the collateral sulcus.

choices.text: Upper and medial quadrant has more tissue
Axillary tail of spence crosses anterior axillary fold

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding breast?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Upper and lateral quadrant of breast has more tissue as it gives rise to Axillary tail of spence. Option B-There are 15-20 lobules present in breast. Option C-Axillary tail of spence crosses anterior axillary fold is a true statement.Spence tail is the prolongation of upper outer quadrant of the breast in the axillary direction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of Superior oblique?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-The superior oblique muscle's primary action is eye intorsion, with secondary and tertiary actions being eye depression and abduction, respectively. Option D-Adduction is not a function of Superior oblique.It is done by medial rectus and superior and inferior rectus.

questions.text: Which of the following passes between superior & middle constrictor?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles, the stylopharyngeus muscle and the glossopharyngeal nerve passes through. Between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscles, the internal laryngeal nerve and the superior laryngeal artery and vein passes through.

questions.text: Drooping of angle of mouth after parotidectomy due to damage of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cervical branch

questions.text: Not a joint type seen in vertebral bone ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-At a synchondrosis, the bones are united by hyaline cartilage. The epiphyseal plate of growing long bones and the first sternocostal joint that unites the first rib to the sternum are examples of synchondroses.This is not seen in vertebral joints. Option B-A symphysis is a fibrocartilaginous fusion between two bones. It is specifically a secondary cartilaginous joint. Option C-A syndesmosis is "a joint where two bones are held together by ligaments." Option D-Plain joints have bones with articulating surfaces and are found in the tarsal bones of the foot, carpal bones of the hands, and also in between vertebrae. An example of such a joint type is the wrist carpals.

questions.text: Trigeminal spinal nucleus, second order neuron is for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The trigeminal nerve is the fifth cranial nerve and is responsible for sensation in the face. The trigeminal nerve has three major branches: the ophthalmic nerve (V1), the maxillary nerve (V2), and the mandibular nerve (V3). In the trigeminal sensory pathway, sensory information from the face is carried by the trigeminal nerve to the trigeminal ganglion, which contains the cell bodies of the primary sensory neurons. From there, the sensory information is transmitted to the trigeminal nerve's central processes, which synapse in the trigeminal sensory nucleus located in the brainstem. The trigeminal sensory nucleus consists of three main parts: 1. The main sensory nucleus - which carries discriminative touch and conscious proprioception information. 2. The spinal trigeminal nucleus - which carries pain and temperature information. 3. The mesencephalic nucleus - which carries proprioceptive information from the muscles of mastication. In the trigeminal sensory pathway, the second-order neurons for pain and temperature information from the face are located in the spinal trigeminal nucleus. These second-order neurons receive input from the primary sensory neurons in the trigeminal ganglion and transmit the information to higher brain centers for processing and perception.

questions.text: Which of the marked area shows calcification?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-A is bone of epiphyseal region. Option B-B is zone of resting cartilage. Option C-C is zone of proliferation. Option D-Marked area of zone D is zone of calcified matrix which shows calcification.

questions.text: Which of the following supplies the marked area as shown in the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Left Circumflex artery supplies left atrium and left ventricle. Option B-Marked area is supplied by conus artery.It supplies blood flow to the conus, the right ventricular outflow tract and a large portion of the anterior free wall of the right ventricle. Option C-Diagonal artery supplies left ventricle. Option D-Marginal artery supplies right ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct match? 1 –Aldosterone 2 –Epinephrine/Norepinephrine 3 –Sex Steroid 4 –Cortisol
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aldosterone is secreted by zona glomerulosa. Cortisol is secreted by zona fasciculata. Sex Steroid is secreted by zona reticularis. Epinephrine/Norepinephrine is secreted by adrenal medulla. therefore, answer is A-1, B-4, C-3, D-2 Zona Glomerulosa: • Present Immediately inside the capsule • Comprising about 15% of the cortex • Consists of closely packed, rounded or arched cords of columnar or pyramidal cells with many capillaries . • Aldosterone, the major regulator of salt balance which acts to stimulate Na + reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules is principal product. Middle Zona Fasciculata: • Occupies 65% to 80% of the cortex. • Consists of long cords of large polyhedral cells • These cells secrete: Glucocorticoids, especially cortisol, which affect carbohydrate metabolism by stimulating gluconeogenesis in many cells and glycogen synthesis in the liver. Zona Reticularis: • The innermost Zona Reticularis comprises about 10% of the cortex. • Consists of smaller cells in a network of irregular cords interspersed with wide capillaries The cells are usually more heavily stained, than those of the other zones • Cells of the also produce cortisol, But primarily secrete the weak androgens, • Including dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) that is converted to testosterone in both men and women. Adrenal Medulla: • Is composed of large, pale-staining polyhedral cells arranged in cords or clumps and supported by a reticular fiber network. • For storage and secretion of catecholamines, Either Epinephrine or Norepinephrine.

questions.text: what is the section of vertebral level as shown in picture ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In this image we can see Epiploic Foramen/Omental Foramen/Foramen of Winslow is located behind the right free margin of the lesser omentum, at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra.It connects lesser sac with greater sac.Hence,It is the sectoion at T12 vertebra.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is supplied by Lateral plantar nerve ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C,D-Medial plantar nerve supplies 4 intrinsic muscles of sole. These are abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis, flexor hallucis brevis and 1st lumbrical. Option B-1st Interossei is supplied by Lateral plantar nerve.Rest of muscles of sole are supplied by Lateral plantar nerve.

questions.text: Patient's right hip drops while taking the right foot off of the ground. All of the following are involved except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-The purpose of the Trendelenburg Test is to identify the weakness of the hip abductors.A positive Trendelenburg sign usually indicates weakness in the hip abductor muscles:Gluteus Medius and Gluteus Minimus,both of which are supplied by Superior Gluteal Nerve. Option D-Sciatic nerve do not supply hip muscles. This test is performed in standing: Position the patient standing on one leg for 30 seconds. The patient may hold onto a support if needed for balance. Observe whether the pelvis remains level during the single-leg stance. A positive Trendelenburg Test is indicated by a drop of the pelvis on the contralateral (unsupported) side. This may also be identified during gait, where the trunk compensates by side-flexing towards the involved side during the stance phase.

questions.text: Which sulcus lies deep to marked area?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The marked area is pterion and Stem of Lateral sulcus lies deep to it. Option B,C,D-Inferior frontal sulcus,Intra Parietal sulcus and Central sulcus are located well away from pterion.

questions.text: Which Structure develops from the marked area?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Kidney develops from intermediate mesoderm. Option B-The marked structure is paraaxial mesoderm which gives rise to axial skeleton like ribs. Option C-Parietal Pleura develops from somatopleuric mesoderm. Option D-Dorsal root ganglion develops from neural crest cells.

choices.text: Internal oblique and Transverse Abdominis makes roof

questions.text: Regarding Inguinal Canal, which of the following is correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Anterior wall is formed by External oblique. Option B-Internal oblique and transverse Abdominis arches over and makes the roof of inguinal canal. Option C-Fascia Transversalis makes posterior wall of inguinal canal. Option D-floor is made by inguinal canal.

questions.text: Apocrine sweat glands are present in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Apocrine glands in the skin and eyelid are sweat glands. Most apocrine glands in the skin are in the armpits, the groin, and the area around the nipples of the breast. Apocrine glands in the skin are scent glands, and their secretions usually have an odor. Option B,C,D-Scalp,palm and Face have eccrine glands.

choices.text: Left adrenal is near the tail of pancreas and Spleen

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about adrenal gland?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-adrenal glands are yellow coloured structure. Option B-adrenal glands are Retroperitoneal in location. Option C-Right adrenal is traiangular in shape while left adrenal is semilunar in shape. Option D-Left adrenal is located near the tail of pancreas and Spleen.

questions.text: Which of the following is the function of marked layer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Gluconeogenesis is produced by cortisol,which is produced by zona fasciculata. Option B-sex hormones secretion is done by zona reticulata. Option C-Immune cell modulation is done by cortisol,which is produced by zona fasciculata. Option D-Sodium & water retention is done by aldosterone,which is produced by zona glomerulosa as marked in picture.

questions.text: Identify the marked Structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Ascending aorta is located anteriorly. Option B-Pulmonary trunk divides into two pulmonary arteries, just behind ascending aorta. Option C-Oesophagus is situated just anterior to vertebral column. Option D-SVC is located on the right side and opens into right atrium.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The subaortic curtain is part of the fibrous skeleton of the heart. It is a fibrous sheet that spans the gap between the fibrous arches supporting the right posterior and left posterior leaflets of the aortic valve. Option B-Cusp of mitral valve will be seen within right AV orifice. Option C-Cusp of Aortic valve will be seen within left AV orifice. Option D-Anterior aortic sinus is located within the initial segment of ascending aorta.

questions.text: IncudoMalleolar is what type of joint?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-IncudoMalleolar is Saddle joint. Option B-Ball & Socket joint is present at incudostapedial joint. Option C-Pivot joint is a synovial joint in which the ends of two bones connect. In this joint, a cylinder-shaped bone rotates inside another ligament that forms a ring around the joint. The joint between the atlas and the axis which is right under the skull, allows the turning of the head from side to side. Option D-Condylar joints are found in the wrist, toes, and fingers.

questions.text: Which of the following drains into IVC ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Left Gonadal Vein drains into left renal vein. Option B-Left Suprarenal Vein drains into left renal vein. Option C-Left inferior phrenic Vein drains into IVC. Option D-Right ascending lumbar vein drains into azygos vein.

questions.text: Artery supplying the marked area is a branch of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The marked area is of lateral part of medulla,whose involvment leads to wallenburg syndrome.which most commonly occurs due to lesion in vertebral artery>PICA. Option B-Basilar Artery supplies pons. Option C-Superior Cerebellar Artery supplies superior surface of cerebellum. Option D-Posterior Cerebral Artery supplies occipital lobe.

questions.text: Patient suffered from medial epicondyle fracture.Which nerve is injured in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Median Nerve lies in cubital fossa. Option B-Ulnar Nerve lies behind medial epicondyle.Hence,ulnar nerve is injured in this patient. Option C-Axillary Nerve lies around surgical neck of humerus. Option D-Radial Nerve is present in spiral groove of humerus.

questions.text: Superior Gluteal nerve supplies all of the following except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C,D-Gluteus Medius,Gluteus Minimus and Tensor Fascia Lata are supplied by Superior Gluteal nerve. Option B-Nerve Supply of the Piriformis Muscle is from the ventral rami of the lower spinal nerves of the sacral plexus S1 and S2.

questions.text: SRY gene is present on:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) SRY gene is present on Short arm of Y chromosome.SRY (which stands for sex-determining region Y gene) is found on the Y chromosome. In the cell, it binds to other DNA and in doing so distorts it dramatically out of shape. This alters the properties of the DNA and likely alters the expression of a number of genes, leading to testis formation.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the marked muscle as shown in picture? A. Retracts the scapula along with the trapezius B. Elevates the scapula along with the trapezius C. Rotates the scapula so that glenoid cavity tilts upwards D. Rotates the scapula so that glenoid cavity tilts downwards
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Based on anatomical functions, options A, B, and D are all correct statements regarding the actions of the rhomboid minor muscle A. Retracts the scapula along with the trapezius: This statement describes a core function of the rhomboid muscles. Scapular retraction (or adduction) involves pulling the scapula medially, closer to the vertebral column. The rhomboids are very powerful retractors. The middle fibers of the trapezius muscle also play a significant role in scapular retraction. Therefore, the rhomboid minor indeed retracts the scapula along with the trapezius. This statement is correct. B. Elevates the scapula along with the trapezius: The rhomboid muscles do contribute to scapular elevation, which means lifting the scapula superiorly. While the upper fibers of the trapezius are well-known as strong elevators of the scapula, the rhomboids, by pulling the scapula medially and slightly superiorly, also assist in this action. So, the rhomboid minor can elevate the scapula along with the trapezius (specifically, the upper fibers). This statement is also correct. C. Rotates the scapula so that glenoid cavity tilts upwards: This statement describes upward rotation of the scapula, where the glenoid cavity (the shallow socket that articulates with the head of the humerus) rotates superiorly. This action is primarily performed by the upper trapezius, lower trapezius, and serratus anterior muscles. The rhomboid muscles actually have the opposite effect; they cause downward rotation of the scapula. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. D. Rotates the scapula so that glenoid cavity tilts downwards: This statement describes downward rotation of the scapula, where the glenoid cavity tilts inferiorly. This is a very important and direct action of the rhomboid muscles, working in conjunction with muscles like the levator scapulae and pectoralis minor. This statement is correct.

questions.text: A Patient presents with Nystagmus and vomiting. On examination, there is loss of pain and temperature on left side of face and right side of body. Also there is hoarseness of voice. Which artery is involved in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nystagmus and vomiting occurs due to cerebellum involvement. loss of pain and temperature on left side of face occurs due to left side spinal nucleus of trigemenial nerve involvement. loss of pain and temperature on right side of body occurs due to left side spinal meniscus involvement. hoarseness of voice occurs due to vagus nerve involvement. The above structures are involved in lateral medullary syndrome/wallenburg syndrome. This syndrome occurs most commonly due to vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

questions.text: Match the following columns 1. Pelvic 2. Retrocaecal 3. Subcaecal 4. Preileal
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 1. Pelvic-C 2. Retrocaecal-A 3. Subcaecal-B 4. Preileal-D

questions.text: Anterior relations of 3rd part of Duodenum are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Superior mesenteric vessels lies anterior to 3rd part of duodenum. Option B-Root of mesentery also lies anterior to 3rd part of duodenum. Option C-Gall bladder lies anterior to 1st part of duodenum. Option D-Jejunal coils also lies anterior to 3rd part of duodenum.

questions.text: Arrange the columns from Medial to lateral? 1) SVA 2) SVE 3) SSA 4) GSA
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) From Medial to lateral,the arrangement is as follows:- SVE-special visceral efferent SVA-special visceral afferent GSA-general somatic afferent SSA-special somatic afferent

questions.text: Arrange the structures from peripheral to central order in Auditory pathway? 1. Spiral ganglion 2. Cochlear nucleus 3. Inferior colliculus 4. Lateral lemniscus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Auditory pathway can be remembered with Mnemonic as follows:-ECOLI MA Eight nerve from spiral ganglion Cochlear nucleus superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following is first formed by the migration of epiblast cells?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Ectoderm is the last layer to be formed. Option B-Mesoderm is the 2nd layer to be formed. Option C-endoderm is the first layer formed by the migration of epiblast cells through primitve streak. Option D-Neural crest cells arises from neuroectoderm.

questions.text: Mitochondria is present in which of the following parts of sperm?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Head contains nucleus and acrosome. Option B-Neck contains centrioles. Option C-Mitochondria is present in Middle piece of sperm. Option D-Tail is long filamentous structure.

questions.text: Oocyte is arrested in which phase of meiosis at Birth?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Oocyte is arrested in Diplotene stage of meiosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is marked in the given picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Primitive streak is a groove present in caudal region of epiblast. Option B-The neural folds extend towards the dorsal midline where they meet and fuse. This fusion forms the roof of the neural tube and results in this fully separating from the overlying epidermal ectoderm, which contributes to developing the skin layer of the back of the embryo. Option C-Notochord is present in midline. Option D-Neural groove is a groove present in midline,due to elevation of neural folds.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of Neural crest cells?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Retinal pigment epithelium originate from neuroectodermal cells. Option B,C,D-Ciliary ganglion,Ciliary muscle and Adrenal medulla are derivatives of Neural crest cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is marked in given angiogram?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A- The MCA is part of the circle of Willis anastomotic system within the brain, which forms when the anterior cerebral arteries anastomose anteriorly with each other through the anterior communicating artery and posteriorly with the two posterior communicating arteries bridging the MCA with the posterior cerebral artery on each side. Option B-The internal carotid arteries are branches of the common carotid arteries that bifurcate into the internal and external carotids at the level of the carotid sinus.After this bifurcation, the internal carotids traverse through the base of the skull to reach the vital organs that they supply. Option C-Basilar Artery is located on anterior surface of pons. Option D-Your superficial temporal artery sends blood to your scalp and face. It starts below your ear and runs vertically between your cheekbone and your ear.

questions.text: Which sulcus lies deep to marked area?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve is marked in the given picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 3rd

questions.text: Which of the following features will be seen in case of posterior interosseous nerve injury.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Wrist drop do not occur in case of posterior interosseous nerve injury,as brachioradialis and ECRL are spared. Option B-Loss of finger extension occur in case of posterior interosseous nerve injury. Option C-Inability to extend elbow do not occur as triceps is spared. Option D-Inability to abduct little fingers occur in ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text: A patient complains of food stucking between cheek and teeth. Which of the following muscles is responsible for this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Buccinator helps in clearing food stuck between cheek and teeth. Option B-Risorius helps in smiling. Option C-Orbicularis oris helps in poutting of mouth. Option D-Zygomaticus major helps in facial expression.

questions.text: Which of the following passes through the gap between superior and middle constrictor muscles:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Styloglossus is a muscle of tongue and is supplied by hypoglossal nerve. Option B-Stylopharyngeus passes through the gap between superior and middle constrictor muscles. Option C,D-Superior Laryngeal Artery and Internal Laryngeal Nerve pierces thyrohyoid membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following opens in the space marked as no-7
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Looking at the provided image: Based on typical anatomical landmarks in a coronal view of the nasal cavity: 1. Olfactory Bulb / Cribriform Plate region: This number points to the superior-most aspect of the nasal cavity, near the roof, where the olfactory bulb would sit above the cribriform plate. 2. Orbit / Eye: This points to the orbital cavity, which contains the eye. 3. Superior Turbinate (Concha): This is the superior-most of the three conchae. 4. Superior Meatus (or possibly part of the Superior Turbinate): This space lies inferior to the superior turbinate. 5. Middle Turbinate (Concha): This is the middle concha. 6. Middle Meatus: This space lies inferior to the middle turbinate. The openings of the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoid sinuses are typically located in this meatus or its anterior part (hiatus semilunaris/ethmoid bulla). 7. Inferior Turbinate (Concha): This is the largest and most inferior concha. 8. Inferior Meatus: This space lies inferior to the inferior turbinate. The nasolacrimal duct opens into this meatus. 9. Nasal Septum: This is the cartilaginous and bony wall that divides the nasal cavity into right and left halves. Number 7 points to the inferior turbinate. The space inferior and lateral to the inferior turbinate is the inferior meatus, where the nasolacrimal duct opens. Therefore, the nasolacrimal duct opens into the region associated with number 7 (inferior turbinate, specifically into the inferior meatus below it).

questions.text: Not features of 3rd nerve palsy
questions.solution: Correct Answer(D)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of Sup oblique?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Hemiballismus is caused by which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Subthalamic nucleus. Hemiballismus is a rare neurological movement disorder characterized by involuntary, forceful, and large-amplitude flinging or flailing movements of the limbs on one side of the body. It's almost always caused by a lesion, most commonly a stroke, affecting the contralateral subthalamic nucleus (STN).

questions.text: Trendelenburg test is positive. what is the action of affected muscle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer(B)

questions.text: Q nerve affected in right trendelenberg positive?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right superior gluteal nerve. This nerve supplies the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which are the primary abductors of the hip. During normal gait, when a person stands on the right leg, these abductors on the right side contract to keep the pelvis level and prevent the opposite side from dropping. If the right superior gluteal nerve is damaged, these muscles become weak or paralyzed. As a result, when the patient stands on the right leg, the left side of the pelvis drops because there is no effective abductor pull to stabilize the pelvis. This phenomenon is called a positive Trendelenburg sign on the right side. The clinical importance lies in identifying the side of nerve injury correctly, since the pelvic drop always occurs on the opposite side to the lesion. Thus, a positive right Trendelenburg test indicates that the right superior gluteal nerve, which controls the right hip abductors, is affected.

questions.text: Which of the marked structure is Merocrine gland :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Structure C points to a coiled, tubular gland located deep in the dermis. This morphology is characteristic of an eccrine sweat gland. Eccrine sweat glands are the primary type of sweat gland and are classified as merocrine glands. Merocrine secretion involves the release of secretory products by exocytosis, where vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane and release their contents without any loss of cellular material. This is the mechanism by which eccrine glands secrete sweat. Incorrect Options: Other options (A. A) Explanation: Structure A points to a hair shaft within a hair follicle. The hair shaft is a keratinized structure and is not a gland. Other Options (B. B) Explanation: Structure B points to a sebaceous gland. These glands are typically associated with hair follicles and secrete an oily substance called sebum. Sebaceous glands are classified as holocrine glands, meaning their secretory product is released by the rupture of the entire cell, leading to cell death and replacement. Other Options (D. D) Explanation: Structure D points to the hair bulb/dermal papilla region at the base of a hair follicle. Th

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining that he has food stuck in his throat. His symptoms started 2 hours ago after eating fish at a local seafood restaurant. He has tried coughing and swallowing multiple times in an attempt to clear the food, but has so far been unsuccessful. The patient denies any difficulty with breathing He does not appear to be in any distress on physical examination. Laryngoscopy reveals a fish bone lodged in the left piriform recess. While trying to retrieye the fish bone, a nerve is injured deep to the mucosa overlying the recess. Which of the following is most likely to be impaired in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which of the following mechanism is used by the marked structure to influence neighbouring cell?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The image shows a histological section of the pancreas. The large, paler-staining cluster of cells marked by the arrow is a pancreatic islet (also known as the Islet of Langerhans). This is the endocrine part of the pancreas, which is responsible for producing and secreting hormones like insulin and glucagon. The darker-staining surrounding tissue is the exocrine pancreas, made up of acinar cells that produce digestive enzymes. The cells within the islet and the surrounding exocrine cells influence each other's function through paracrine signaling. This is a type of local cell-to-cell communication where a cell secretes signaling molecules (like hormones) that act on nearby cells by diffusing through the interstitial fluid. For example, insulin secreted by the islet's beta cells can inhibit glucagon secretion from neighboring alpha cells and also influence the enzyme production of the surrounding acinar cells. A. Nerve mediated: While the pancreas has rich nervous innervation, the primary mechanism of communication between the endocrine and exocrine parts of the pancreas is not direct neural signaling but rather hormonal. B. Vein mediated: This would describe endocrine signaling, where hormones are secreted into the bloodstream (veins) to act on distant target cells. While the islets do this (e.g., insulin acting on the liver), the question asks about the influence on neighboring cells. D. Epithelium to mesothelium transformation: This is a process of cellular change that is not relevant to the function of a mature pancreas and does not describe a signaling mechanism.
